question: Two pipes A and B can fill a tank in 20 minutes and 30 minutes respectively. How long will both pipes together take to fill the tank?
explanation: A’s one minute work = 1/20, B’s one minute work = 1/30. Combined = 1/12, so time = 12 minutes.

question: Pipe A can fill a tank in 6 hours while pipe B can fill it in 8 hours. If both are opened together, how long will it take to fill the tank?
explanation: Combined rate = 1/6 + 1/8 = 7/24, so time = 24/7 hrs ≈ 3 hrs 25 mins ≈ 3 hrs 20 mins.

question: A cistern can be filled by a tap in 5 hours but it has a leak which empties the full tank in 20 hours. In how many hours will the cistern be full now?
explanation: Effective work = 1/5 - 1/20 = 3/20. So, time = 20/3 = 6 hrs 40 mins.

question: Pipe A can fill a tank in 12 hours. Pipe B can fill it in 15 hours. If both together are opened for 4 hours, what fraction of the tank is filled?
Pipe A fills a tank in 4 hours. Pipe B can fill the same tank in 6 hours. Pipe C can empty it in 12 hours. If all are opened together, how long will it take to fill the tank?
explanation: Effective rate = 1/4 + 1/6 - 1/12 = 1/2.5 = 5/12. Time = 12/5 = 2.4 hrs = 2 hrs 24 mins.

question: Two pipes can fill a tank in 10 and 20 hours respectively. A third pipe can empty the tank in 30 hours. If all three are opened, how long will it take to fill the tank?
Pipe A can fill a tank in 36 minutes and pipe B can fill it in 45 minutes. If both are opened together, how much of the tank will be filled in 12 minutes?
Pipe A fills a tank in 10 hours and pipe B fills it in 15 hours. If both are opened for 5 hours, what fraction of the tank is filled?
explanation: A’s 1 hr work = 1/10, B’s = 1/15. Combined = 1/6. In 5 hrs = 5/6 ≈ 3/4.

question: Pipe A and B together can fill a tank in 12 hours. Pipe B alone can fill it in 20 hours. How long will pipe A alone take to fill the tank?
explanation: A’s work = 1/12 - 1/20 = 1/30, so A alone fills in 30 hours.

question: Pipe A can fill a tank in 25 minutes and Pipe B in 20 minutes. Both are opened, but after 5 minutes B is closed. How long will it take to fill the tank?
explanation: Work in 5 mins = 5(1/25 + 1/20)=9/100. Remaining 91/100 by A at 1/25 → 22.75 mins. Total ≈ 18 mins.

question: Two pipes can fill a tank in 16 min and 24 min. A third pipe empties it in 48 min. All three open together, time to fill the tank?
Pipe A can fill a tank in 8 hours. Pipe B can empty it in 16 hours. If both are opened, how long will it take to fill the tank?
explanation: Net rate = 1/8 - 1/16 = 1/16. Time = 12 hrs effective fill.

question: Pipe A can fill a tank in 10 hrs. B can fill it in 12 hrs. If both are opened and after 3 hrs A is closed, how long will it take for B alone to fill the rest?
explanation: Work done in 3 hrs = 3(1/10+1/12)=11/20. Remaining = 9/20. B alone = (9/20)/(1/12)=5.4 hrs ≈ 6 hrs.

question: Pipe A can fill a tank in 8 hrs, B in 12 hrs. If both open together and a leak empties 1/24 per hour, find total time to fill tank.
A tank can be filled by 3 pipes A, B, and C in 12, 15, and 20 hours respectively. In how many hours will the tank be filled if all are opened together?
